@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC I am looking forward to more chats in the future. It was great to discuss the strides we have made in bridging the #DigitalDivide, closing the #HomeworkGap, and the work that still needs to be done to improve access to education for all. #TelecomActChat

@FCC The pandemic highlighted and exacerbated the issues we were already aware of with the #DigitalDivide. Many households do not have access to broadband and that leaves them behind in school, jobs, and everyday life. We need connections now more than ever. #TelecomActChat

@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC So much of school today requires the internet. We risk widening the achievement gap if we do not fix this soon. We need to make sure the internet is affordable and accessible for everyone. #TelecomActChat

@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC The #homeworkgap needs attention. Millions of kids across this country‚Äîin rural and urban and everywhere in between‚Äîcan not do their homework or participate in class during the #COVID19 pandemic because they cannot get online. #TelecomActChat

@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC This is an issue that is close to my heart. It is something that I have seen firsthand - students struggling through lack of internet access in Waterbury, Connecticut. #TelecomActChat
@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC But now, we need to expand #ERate beyond schools and into the homes of students as so many kids are learning remotely during this pandemic. #TelecomActChat
@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC #ERate and being able to use the internet to expand my students‚Äô horizons was critical. #TelecomActChat

@FCC This bill created a Universal Service Fund to support access by those in rural areas, as well as low-income Americans. It demonstrated that broadband connectivity must reach all Americans, regardless of who they are or where they live. #TelecomActChat

@FCC The Telecom Act started us down the path of ever-expanding network connectivity. It recognized the importance of digital access and equity ‚Äì something we are still working on today. And it codified the idea that the internet should be affordable for all.  #TelecomActChat

@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC As a career educator, I am especially interested in how this law brought the internet into schools and libraries. How it has changed how teachers teach and students learn. #TelecomActChat

@JRosenworcelFCC @FCC Thanks @FCC & Acting Chairwoman @JRosenworcelFCC for chatting today. It is always a privilege to take a break from my day job in Congress and return to what I love best - teaching. #TelecomActChat

They strategically brought other photo-friendly allies, including Mary Parkman Peabody, a 72-year-old white woman and mother of the Governor of Massachusetts. Her arrest, like the pool photos, spurred the national press to cast the movement's struggles in a different light. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EttoRWyXAAA8cvK.jpg

The following day, the Civil Rights Act was approved. J.T. Johnson, one of the swimmers in the pool that day, later said "I'm not so sure the Civil Rights Act would have been passed had [there] not been a St. Augustine. It was a milestone." https://www.npr.org/2014/06/13/321380585/remembering-a-civil-rights-swim-in-it-was-a-milestone

The movement was the only time and place where Dr. King was arrested in Florida. 16 Jewish rabbis were also jailed (the largest mass arrest of rabbis in American history). Brave protesters jumped into a "Whites only" pool and had acid dumped on them (pictured: Mimi Ford). http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ettq9WFWgAQwiUL.jpg

Katherine "Kat" Twine, the "Rosa Parks of St. Augustine," was arrested so many times that she kept a bag packed by the door for when they came to arrest her, and carried around a large-brimmed hat (her "Freedom Hat") so that she would have some shade in the stockades. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EttlO_2XYAAxoMg.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EttlQckXAAEOvHx.jpg

The Civil Rights Act was deadlocked and filibustered. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and others joined Dr. Hayling in St. Augustine. They marched nightly, enduring assaults and incarcerations outside in the hot sun. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EttlEfsXEAMVB3R.jpg

The sheriff arrested four KKK members, AND the four Black men, who were accused of "assaulting" the mob.
 
Charges against the klansmen were dropped. Dr. Hayling was convicted of "criminal assault."
 
The next spring, in 1964, Dr. Hayling put out his call.

He advocated for Black residents to be recognized at the anniversary.
 
In response, he and three others were kidnapped, brought to a Klan rally, beaten, and nearly burned alive.
 
Klan members fired into his home, killing his dog and just missing his pregnant wife. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ettp1yRWgAM_gvH.jpg

Dr. Hayling had attended @FAMU_1887 & served in the @usairforce.
 
In 1960, he moved to St. Augustine, which was just a few years from celebrating its "400th anniversary as the nation‚Äôs oldest city on an all-white basis." http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ettkj6lXUAMP9R8.jpg

In spring of 1964, Dr. Robert Hayling, a Black dentist and civil rights leader in St. Augustine, FL, called for college students to come spend their spring breaks not on the beach but at nonviolent civil rights protests.
 
They came. (Thread) #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EttkfSLXIAMCQV2.jpg

It‚Äôs just common sense:

Presidents must be accountable for their offenses, whether they occur on the first day of their term or the last.

Our Founders agreed. The history of the impeachment power agrees. There‚Äôs no ‚ÄúJanuary exemption.‚Äù

Trump must be convicted. http://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/EtvklH1XMAIW9bR.jpg https://video.twimg.com/tweet_video/EtvklH1XMAIW9bR.mp4

But enough about Britain.
 
In 1876, the U.S. Secretary of War William Belknap was impeached for accepting a bribe.

He was impeached *while* he was in office. He faced trial *after* he left office. The Senate voted 37-29 that former officials could be tried.

Sound familiar?

The Founders accepted this view of impeachment, and adopted it when drafting our Constitution.
 
They also recognized that impeachment had to have ‚Äúteeth,‚Äù so no one could escape accountability by leaving office.

Disqualification from future office was always essential! http://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/EtvkdCEWYAQWbB8.jpg https://video.twimg.com/tweet_video/EtvkdCEWYAQWbB8.mp4

Parliament impeached the former Lord Chancellor in 1725 for acts of bribery during his term.

And in 1787, while America's Founders met to draft our Constitution, Warren Hastings of Britain was impeached for abuses he committed while Governor-General of Bengal.

Our Founders didn‚Äôt invent impeachment from scratch. Oh no.

According to Hamilton, they looked to Britain which provided ‚Äúthe model from which the idea of this institution has been borrowed.‚Äù
 
In the 18th Century, British Parliament impeached two men ‚Äì both *former* officials. http://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/EtvkSs_XMAAMlw-.jpg https://video.twimg.com/tweet_video/EtvkSs_XMAAMlw-.mp4

You're going to hear a lot of bad faith arguments about impeachment.

Trump‚Äôs team will argue you can‚Äôt convict former officials or presidents.

But history shows otherwise! And the Founders disagreed, too.

Let's turn to 18th Century Britain. (Stay with me, folks)
